dsls.markdown:
# Your Digital Footprint

Putting information about yourself online creates a digital footprint.

# Move It, Move It

Use a map and give commands to reach the goal.

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.short_instructions: For this puzzle, snap the blocks together and click "▶ Run"!
https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.long_instructions: To get the bird to the pig, snap the [blockly block][0] block to the bottom of the [blockly block][1] block, then press "▶ Run"!

authored_hints.courseC_maze_programming1_a: If the bird isn't getting to the pig, make sure both of the blocks have been fully clicked together, then click "Run" again.
authored_hints.courseC_maze_programming1_b: Don't be afraid to make a mistake! Try something, and if it doesn't work, try something else!

callouts.grade2_CaringForNewPet_0_1: After snapping all the blocks together, press "Run" to start your program.

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.short_instructions: Snap all blocks together to finish your code, then click "Run".
https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.long_instructions: Attach both [blockly block][0] blocks to the [blockly block][1] block to finish your code, then click "▶ Run".

dsls.markdown:
# Getting Loopy

This lesson introduces the programming concept of loops through a dance activity.

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.short_instructions: Help the harvester pick all the corn!
https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.long_instructions: Help the harvester pick all the corn!

authored_hints.courseA_harvester_loops1_a:
Once you move to some corn, use this block to pick it!

[blockly block][0]

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.short_instructions: Make sure to pick all the corn!
https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.long_instructions: The harvester needs to pick all the corn! Do you see a pattern?

authored_hints.courseA_harvester_loops2_a:
Your code will have **four** `move west`

[blockly block][0]

blocks and **four** [blockly block][1] blocks.
authored_hints.courseA_harvester_loops2_b: If you're still having trouble, try saying the steps out loud.

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.short_instructions: Can you pick all the corn using only **one** move block?
https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.long_instructions: Can you pick all the corn using only **one** move block?

authored_hints.courseA_harvester_loops3_a:
Use a `repeat` block like this to help you!

[blockly block][0]

Can you help the harvester find the bug in her code?

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.long_instructions:
**Free Play:** Move Laurel around and get as much treasure as you can. Get at least one item with no mistakes to pass this level.  

* * *

Drag blocks into the workspace and try to figure out how to get treasure.

authored_hints.courseB_collector_loops_challenge2a_a: If something goes wrong, try debugging it. Don't give up!
authored_hints.courseB_collector_loops_challenge2a_b: Look at this option for getting through the maze. Do you see a pattern that you can repeat?
authored_hints.courseB_collector_loops_challenge2a_c: To collect all of the treasure, you will either need to add two  [blockly block][0] blocks inside your loop, or put the block inside of its own `repeat` block.

authored_hints.courseB_artist_loops7_a: This challenge uses **4** loops, one right after another!
authored_hints.courseB_artist_loops7_b:
Notice that every loop makes a stair pattern that goes a different direction.

[][0]
authored_hints.courseB_artist_loops7_c:
The loops should do this:

-   Loop 1
    -   Right
    -   Down

-   Loop 2
    -   Right
    -   Up

-   Loop 3
    -   Left
    -   Up

-   Loop 4
    -   Left
    -   Down

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.teacher_markdown:
This is a free-play level. This is not only a great place to point students who are progressing quickly, but a place for all students to really express their creativity. While students are not actually required to write any code in this level, doing so will allow them to apply what they have learned in a way that is more meaningful to them. Encourage your students to take their time here.

-   These levels are **not checked for correctness** to allow for more open-ended creativity. Empower your students to determine for themselves when they have created something they like. There is no one right answer! 
-   Example solutions are available for this level which can be viewed by opening the teacher panel to the right.

authored_hints.courseB_artist_loops_challenge2_a: The code to draw an X is already given to you. All you need to do is repeat the X and `jump` to the next spot.
authored_hints.courseB_artist_loops_challenge2_b: You can use `jump` blocks to move to other spaces without drawing.

dsls.markdown:
# The Right App

* Everyone uses computers these days, especially smartphones. 
* Smartphone apps help people do things like talk to friends, listen to music, shop, or just browse the web.
* It is important for programmers to understand others' needs and design apps with them in mind!

![](https://images.code.org/fb17eeb9238d2f26c6ab40c9841517a7-image-1555611687284.png)

# The Big Event

In computer science, events are actions that a computer monitors. In this lesson you will react differently depending on which button is pressed.

https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.short_instructions: Need a better playlab/events combo
See if you can figure out what each block does.
https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.long_instructions:
This game is called "Play Lab".  

See if you can figure out what each block does.
https://studio.code.org/s/courseb-2019/s.teacher_markdown: This is a free-play level. Because it shows up at the beginning of the lesson, it is intended to serve as a "sandbox" where students can experiment with new blocks While students are not actually required to write any code in this level, doing so will allow them to make discoveries of their own before being asked to perform specific tasks. Encourage your students to take their time here.
